elements.content: A new 3D porous Tb­(III)-ion based PMOF, {[Tb­(L)­(DMA)]·(DMA)·(0.5H2O)} (1) (where L = L3–, H3L = 3′-hydroxybiphenyl-3,4′,5-tricarboxylic acid), with uncoordinated hydroxyl groups decorating the pores has been solvothermally synthesized in moderate yield. The hydroxyl groups act as potential interaction sites to sensitize the luminescence output of the Tb3+ ion. Luminescence studies reveal that the PMOF can selectively and reversibly sense nitroaromatic compounds and Fe­(III) ions in DMF suspension through fluorescence quenching observable under UV light. The probable mechanisms for such sensing processes are, for the nitroaromatic compounds, the host–guest interactions with the PMOF and, for Fe3+ ion, the competitive absorption of excitation energy.
elements.clean_text: A new 3D porous Tb(III)-ion based PMOF, {[Tb(L)(DMA)]⋅(DMA)⋅(0.5H2O)} (1) (where L = L3-, H3L = 3'-hydroxybiphenyl-3,4',5-tricarboxylic acid), with uncoordinated hydroxyl groups decorating the pores has been solvothermally synthesized in moderate yield. The hydroxyl groups act as potential interaction sites to sensitize the luminescence output of the Tb3+ ion. Luminescence studies reveal that the PMOF can selectively and reversibly sense nitroaromatic compounds and Fe(III) ions in DMF suspension through fluorescence quenching observable under UV light. The probable mechanisms for such sensing processes are, for the nitroaromatic compounds, the host-guest interactions with the PMOF and, for Fe3+ ion, the competitive absorption of excitation energy.

elements.content:
A new 3D porous Tb­(III)-ion based PMOF has been synthesized which selectively sense nitroaromatic compounds and Fe­(III) ions in DMF suspension by fluorescence quenching mechanism.

Introduction

Design, synthesis, and characterization of porous metal organic frameworks (PMOFs) continues to be a subject of intense research owing to their various practical applications. Particularly, chemical sensing through change in the luminescence properties of PMOFs is of great practical importance. The capability of host–guest interactions that modulate the luminescence output of PMOFs makes them promising candidates as chemical sensors.
elements.clean_text:
A new 3D porous Tb(III)-ion based PMOF has been synthesized which selectively sense nitroaromatic compounds and Fe(III) ions in DMF suspension by fluorescence quenching mechanism.

Introduction

Design, synthesis, and characterization of porous metal organic frameworks (PMOFs) continues to be a subject of intense research owing to their various practical applications. Particularly, chemical sensing through change in the luminescence properties of PMOFs is of great practical importance. The capability of host-guest interactions that modulate the luminescence output of PMOFs makes them promising candidates as chemical sensors.

elements.content: Sensing of nitroaromatic compounds (NACs) as well as cations, especially Fe3+ ions, is of practical significance. Nitroaromatic compounds pose serious environmental hazards due to their explosive nature. For example, compounds such as nitrobenzene (NB), 4-nitrotoluene (NT), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (DNT), trinitrotoluene (TNT), and so on are on the list of antiterrorism or environmental security in different countries. Trinitrophenol (TNP) is very toxic to human health, and its usage in the chemical industry may lead to fatal environmental consequences. Metabolism of TNP generates picramic acid (2-amino-4,6-dinitrophenol) as a byproduct that shows ten times more mutagenic activity than TNP. Due to moderate vapor pressure and limited chemical reactivity, detection of NACs is not easy. Although different analytical techniques are known to detect NACs, they are either very expensive and time-consuming or difficult to operate. However, NACs being electron-deficient compounds can possibly enter into the voids of a porous luminescent PMOF that provides an electron-rich environment. The efficient host–guest interactions can modulate the luminescence characteristics of the PMOF thus providing a rapid, inexpensive technique for the detection of trace quantities of NACs. On the other hand, detection of Fe3+ is also very important since it is a vital element in the environment as well as in biological systems. It is best known for its role in hemoglobin formation, electron transfer, oxygen metabolism processes, the synthesis of DNA and RNA, and so on. Deviation from the normal permissible limit of iron concentration causes serious health disorders. Accumulated data on iron metabolism suggest that alterations in the intracellular pool of “redox-active” iron (also called “chelatable iron”) can contribute substantially to a variety of injurious processes such as ischemia–reperfusion injury, ethanol toxicity, oxidative injury after nutrient deprivation, and so on.
elements.clean_text: Sensing of nitroaromatic compounds (NACs) as well as cations, especially Fe3+ ions, is of practical significance. Nitroaromatic compounds pose serious environmental hazards due to their explosive nature. For example, compounds such as nitrobenzene (NB), 4-nitrotoluene (NT), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (DNT), trinitrotoluene (TNT), and so on are on the list of antiterrorism or environmental security in different countries. Trinitrophenol (TNP) is very toxic to human health, and its usage in the chemical industry may lead to fatal environmental consequences. Metabolism of TNP generates picramic acid (2-amino-4,6-dinitrophenol) as a byproduct that shows ten times more mutagenic activity than TNP. Due to moderate vapor pressure and limited chemical reactivity, detection of NACs is not easy. Although different analytical techniques are known to detect NACs, they are either very expensive and time-consuming or difficult to operate. However, NACs being electron-deficient compounds can possibly enter into the voids of a porous luminescent PMOF that provides an electron-rich environment. The efficient host-guest interactions can modulate the luminescence characteristics of the PMOF thus providing a rapid, inexpensive technique for the detection of trace quantities of NACs. On the other hand, detection of Fe3+ is also very important since it is a vital element in the environment as well as in biological systems. It is best known for its role in hemoglobin formation, electron transfer, oxygen metabolism processes, the synthesis of DNA and RNA, and so on. Deviation from the normal permissible limit of iron concentration causes serious health disorders. Accumulated data on iron metabolism suggest that alterations in the intracellular pool of "redox-active" iron (also called "chelatable iron") can contribute substantially to a variety of injurious processes such as ischemia-reperfusion injury, ethanol toxicity, oxidative injury after nutrient deprivation, and so on.

elements.content: Lanthanide containing PMOFs have drawn immense attention for their sensing applications. The emission from a lanthanide ion is generally weak because it involves spin- and/or parity-forbidden f–f transitions. Integration of these ions with π-conjugated organic linkers enables electron transfer upon excitation from the linker to the lanthanide ion that greatly enhances its characteristic emission. This phenomenon is known as the “antenna effect” (). In lanthanide containing PMOFs, inclusion of guest molecules can alter the emission intensity by interrupting the electron transfer due to favorable host–guest interactions. Since the emission profiles of lanthanide ions are highly characteristic and can be easily observed under a standard UV lamp, it offers advantages over d10 metal ion based PMOF sensors though there are several reports of the d10 metal ion based PMOF showing high selectivity and sensitivity for the detection of NACs. In recent years, a few Eu3+/Tb3+ based luminescent PMOFs have been reported for the detection of nitroaromatics and different metal ions.
elements.clean_text: Lanthanide containing PMOFs have drawn immense attention for their sensing applications. The emission from a lanthanide ion is generally weak because it involves spin- and/or parity-forbidden f-f transitions. Integration of these ions with π-conjugated organic linkers enables electron transfer upon excitation from the linker to the lanthanide ion that greatly enhances its characteristic emission. This phenomenon is known as the "antenna effect" (). In lanthanide containing PMOFs, inclusion of guest molecules can alter the emission intensity by interrupting the electron transfer due to favorable host-guest interactions. Since the emission profiles of lanthanide ions are highly characteristic and can be easily observed under a standard UV lamp, it offers advantages over d10 metal ion based PMOF sensors though there are several reports of the d10 metal ion based PMOF showing high selectivity and sensitivity for the detection of NACs. In recent years, a few Eu3+/Tb3+ based luminescent PMOFs have been reported for the detection of nitroaromatics and different metal ions.

elements.content: “Antenna effect” induced luminescence in 1.
elements.clean_text: 1  "Antenna effect" induced luminescence in 1.

elements.content: In the present work, a new rigid linear linker has been designed to provide uncoordinated hydroxyl groups in the pores. It forms a 3D PMOF, {[Tb­(L)­(DMA)]·(DMA)·(0.5H2O)} (1) (where L = L3–, H3L = 3′-hydroxybiphenyl-3,4′,5-tricarboxylic acid), with uncoordinated hydroxyl groups decorating the channels and hosting highly disordered solvent molecules in the pore. It emits bright visible characteristic green light under a UV lamp. The luminescence is selectively quenched by nitroaromatic compounds and Fe3+ ions in DMF suspension.
elements.clean_text: In the present work, a new rigid linear linker has been designed to provide uncoordinated hydroxyl groups in the pores. It forms a 3D PMOF, {[Tb(L)(DMA)]⋅(DMA)⋅(0.5H2O)} (1) (where L = L3-, H3L = 3'-hydroxybiphenyl-3,4',5-tricarboxylic acid), with uncoordinated hydroxyl groups decorating the channels and hosting highly disordered solvent molecules in the pore. It emits bright visible characteristic green light under a UV lamp. The luminescence is selectively quenched by nitroaromatic compounds and Fe3+ ions in DMF suspension.

elements.content: Reagent grade methyl-4-iodosalicylate, benzyl bromide, PdCl2, and Tb­(NO3)3·6H2O were procured from Sigma-Aldrich and used as received. All solvents were obtained from S. D. Fine Chemicals, India, and purified following established procedures prior to use. Characterizations of the linker have been carried out by a number of spectroscopic techniques as detailed previously. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the compounds were recorded with a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer equipped with nickel filtered Cu Kα radiation. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) (5 °C/min heating rate under nitrogen atmosphere) were performed with a Mettler Toledo Star System. Solid-state as well as dispersed phase absorption and emission spectra were recorded using a UV–vis–NIR spectrophotometer (Varian model Cary 5000) and Jobin Yvon Horiba Fluorolog-3 spectrofluorimeter at room temperature. EDS analysis was done using a tungsten electron microscope (JSM-6010LA; JEOL). Gas adsorption measurements were performed using automatic volumetric BELSORP-MINI-II adsorption equipment.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

Reagent grade methyl-4-iodosalicylate, benzyl bromide, PdCl2, and Tb(NO3)3⋅6H2O were procured from Sigma-Aldrich and used as received. All solvents were obtained from S. D. Fine Chemicals, India, and purified following established procedures prior to use. Characterizations of the linker have been carried out by a number of spectroscopic techniques as detailed previously. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the compounds were recorded with a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer equipped with nickel filtered Cu Kα radiation. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) (5 °C/min heating rate under nitrogen atmosphere) were performed with a Mettler Toledo Star System. Solid-state as well as dispersed phase absorption and emission spectra were recorded using a UV-vis-NIR spectrophotometer (Varian model Cary 5000) and Jobin Yvon Horiba Fluorolog-3 spectrofluorimeter at room temperature. EDS analysis was done using a tungsten electron microscope (JSM-6010LA; JEOL). Gas adsorption measurements were performed using automatic volumetric BELSORP-MINI-II adsorption equipment.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray data of 1 was collected at 100 K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), and the structure solution was completed as described earlier. Several DFIX commands were used for fixing some bond distances due to inherent disorder. The disordered guest solvent molecules could not be located in the successive difference Fourier maps, and hence PLATON squeeze refinement was performed. The crystal and refinement data are collected in Table S1. Selective bond distances and angles are given in Table S2.
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Studies

Single crystal X-ray data of 1 was collected at 100 K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), and the structure solution was completed as described earlier. Several DFIX commands were used for fixing some bond distances due to inherent disorder. The disordered guest solvent molecules could not be located in the successive difference Fourier maps, and hence PLATON squeeze refinement was performed. The crystal and refinement data are collected in Table S1. Selective bond distances and angles are given in Table S2.

elements.content: All the measurements were done at room temperature. For solid state measurements, activated crystals (1′) were ground to powder. To investigate luminescence response in different solvents, 1 mg of the sample (1′) was dispersed in 5 mL of the corresponding solvent, sonicated, and further diluted to equal volume (20 mL) in each case, and emission intensity was measured. For all quantitative measurements, 5 mg of the powered sample (1′) was dispersed in 5 mL of DMF and sonicated until a homogeneous suspension was obtained. This solution was then diluted to 100 mL to afford the DMF-suspended 1′ and used as the stock solution for all the measurements.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Measurements

All the measurements were done at room temperature. For solid state measurements, activated crystals (1') were ground to powder. To investigate luminescence response in different solvents, 1 mg of the sample (1') was dispersed in 5 mL of the corresponding solvent, sonicated, and further diluted to equal volume (20 mL) in each case, and emission intensity was measured. For all quantitative measurements, 5 mg of the powered sample (1') was dispersed in 5 mL of DMF and sonicated until a homogeneous suspension was obtained. This solution was then diluted to 100 mL to afford the DMF-suspended 1' and used as the stock solution for all the measurements.

elements.content:
Synthesis of the linker H3L could be achieved in several steps as illustrated in . Details of the synthetic procedure are given in the Supporting Information.

Synthesis of the Complex: {[Tb­(<italic>L</italic>)­(DMA)]·(DMA)·(0.5H<sub>2</sub>O)}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

This was synthesized by mixing H3L (0.030 g, 0.1 mmol), Tb­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.09 g, 0.2 mmol), DMA (2 mL), and H2O (1 mL) in a Teflon-lined autoclave that was heated under autogenous pressure at 100 °C for 72 h followed by slow cooling to room temperature. The resulting colorless needle-shaped crystals were isolated by filtration in ∼45% yield based on H3L. Anal. Calcd for C23H26N2O9.5Tb: C, 43.07; H, 4.09; N, 4.37%. Found: C, 43.55; H, 4.27; N, 4.17%. IR (cm–1): 3428­(br), 2927(s), 1618­(m), 1518(s), 1454(s), 1375(s), 1296(s), 1211(s), 1010(s), 774(s), 731(s) (Figure S12).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Ligand

Synthesis of the linker H3L could be achieved in several steps as illustrated in . Details of the synthetic procedure are given in the Supporting Information.

Synthesis of the Complex: {[Tb(L)(DMA)]⋅(DMA)⋅(0.5H2O)} n  (1)

This was synthesized by mixing H3L (0.030 g, 0.1 mmol), Tb(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.09 g, 0.2 mmol), DMA (2 mL), and H2O (1 mL) in a Teflon-lined autoclave that was heated under autogenous pressure at 100 °C for 72 h followed by slow cooling to room temperature. The resulting colorless needle-shaped crystals were isolated by filtration in ~45% yield based on H3L. Anal. Calcd for C23H26N2O9.5Tb: C, 43.07; H, 4.09; N, 4.37%. Found: C, 43.55; H, 4.27; N, 4.17%. IR (cm-1): 3428(br), 2927(s), 1618(m), 1518(s), 1454(s), 1375(s), 1296(s), 1211(s), 1010(s), 774(s), 731(s) (Figure S12).

elements.content: The PMOF 1 could be easily synthesized in single crystal form under solvothermal conditions in moderate yields. The single crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that it crystallizes in the tetragonal space group I41/a. The asymmetric unit contains one Tb­(III) ion, one linker (L3–, denoted as L) and one coordinated DMA molecule (a).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The PMOF 1 could be easily synthesized in single crystal form under solvothermal conditions in moderate yields. The single crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that it crystallizes in the tetragonal space group I41/a. The asymmetric unit contains one Tb(III) ion, one linker (L3-, denoted as L) and one coordinated DMA molecule (a).

elements.content: (a) Asymmetric unit of 1, (b) coordination environment around Tb­(III), and (c) binding mode of the linker.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Asymmetric unit of 1, (b) coordination environment around Tb(III), and (c) binding mode of the linker.

elements.content: Each Tb3+ ion is coordinated to eight O atoms: one bidentate carboxylate, five monodentate carboxylate from five different L, and one O atom from a DMA molecule (b). The Tb–O bond distances lie in the range 2.716(8)–2.268(1) Å and are comparable to reported Tb–O bond distances. The binding mode of the carboxylate toward Tb3+ ion is μ6:η1:η1:η1:η2:η1:η1 (c). The linker is completely deprotonated during the reaction and binds Tb3+ ions to form a one-dimensional chain along the crystallographic c-axis with the nearest Tb–Tb distance being 4.330(9) Å (Figure S15a). These chains are interlinked with the linker L along the crystallographic a- and b-axes (Figure S15b,c) forming a three-dimensional box-like structure (). Topological simplification shows that the framework is 6,6-c net forming a new network topology with Schläfli point symbol {413.62}­{48.67} (Figure S15e). The solvent molecules present in the cavity are highly disordered; hence, the exact solvent composition was evaluated by the combination of TGA and elemental analysis and agreement with PLATON calculated solvent accessible void volume (5276 Å3; 45%) of the unit cell. The channel dimensions along the crystallographic c direction are 15.223(3) × 15.223(3) Å2, and the free hydroxyl moieties of the linker are exposed in the channels along the a- and b-axes. Metal-bound DMA molecules are also directed toward the center of the channels as viewed along the c-axis.
elements.clean_text: Each Tb3+ ion is coordinated to eight O atoms: one bidentate carboxylate, five monodentate carboxylate from five different L, and one O atom from a DMA molecule (b). The Tb-O bond distances lie in the range 2.716(8)-2.268(1) Å and are comparable to reported Tb-O bond distances. The binding mode of the carboxylate toward Tb3+ ion is μ6:η1:η1:η1:η2:η1:η1 (c). The linker is completely deprotonated during the reaction and binds Tb3+ ions to form a one-dimensional chain along the crystallographic c-axis with the nearest Tb-Tb distance being 4.330(9) Å (Figure S15a). These chains are interlinked with the linker L along the crystallographic a- and b-axes (Figure S15b,c) forming a three-dimensional box-like structure (). Topological simplification shows that the framework is 6,6-c net forming a new network topology with Schläfli point symbol {413.62}{48.67} (Figure S15e). The solvent molecules present in the cavity are highly disordered; hence, the exact solvent composition was evaluated by the combination of TGA and elemental analysis and agreement with PLATON calculated solvent accessible void volume (5276 Å3; 45%) of the unit cell. The channel dimensions along the crystallographic c direction are 15.223(3) × 15.223(3) Å2, and the free hydroxyl moieties of the linker are exposed in the channels along the a- and b-axes. Metal-bound DMA molecules are also directed toward the center of the channels as viewed along the c-axis.

elements.content: A perspective view of 1 along the crystallographic c-axis (guest free, H atoms are omitted for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 3  A perspective view of 1 along the crystallographic c-axis (guest free, H atoms are omitted for clarity).

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis reveals that the PMOF loses 15% of its weight (calculated 14.98%) up to 120 °C, which corresponds to the loss of lattice water and DMA molecules. The coordinated DMA molecules are removed at higher temperature (up to 270 °C) showing a weight loss of 14% (calculated 13.57%). Complete decomposition of the compound is achieved beyond 400 °C (Figure S13). The powder X-ray diffraction pattern of the synthesized crystals also agrees well with the simulated pattern and confirmed its phase purity. Furthermore, the VT-PXRD data indicate that the overall framework integrity of 1 is retained at temperatures at least up to 150 °C (Figure S14). Single crystals of 1 were kept in EtOH for a week and then heated to 120 °C under 1 mm pressure for 10 h to obtain the activated compound 1′. The powder pattern of 1′ matched well with the original complex 1 (Figure S14). Due to the porous character of the framework and availability of surface functionalized channels of 1, gas adsorption studies were conducted up to a relative pressure (p/p o) of 1.0 bar. Gas adsorption characteristics of 1′ were not significant and hence not pursued further (Figure S29).
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analysis reveals that the PMOF loses 15% of its weight (calculated 14.98%) up to 120 °C, which corresponds to the loss of lattice water and DMA molecules. The coordinated DMA molecules are removed at higher temperature (up to 270 °C) showing a weight loss of 14% (calculated 13.57%). Complete decomposition of the compound is achieved beyond 400 °C (Figure S13). The powder X-ray diffraction pattern of the synthesized crystals also agrees well with the simulated pattern and confirmed its phase purity. Furthermore, the VT-PXRD data indicate that the overall framework integrity of 1 is retained at temperatures at least up to 150 °C (Figure S14). Single crystals of 1 were kept in EtOH for a week and then heated to 120 °C under 1 mm pressure for 10 h to obtain the activated compound 1'. The powder pattern of 1' matched well with the original complex 1 (Figure S14). Due to the porous character of the framework and availability of surface functionalized channels of 1, gas adsorption studies were conducted up to a relative pressure (p/p o) of 1.0 bar. Gas adsorption characteristics of 1' were not significant and hence not pursued further (Figure S29).

elements.content: The solid-state photoluminescence spectra of the free linker (H3L) and 1′ were measured under ambient conditions by exciting at 345 and 350 nm respectively (). It is well-known that Tb3+ ion exhibits luminescence properties due to f–f transitions that are both spin- and parity-forbidden, thereby having low intensity. However, its emission intensity can be enhanced by integrating Tb3+ ions with conjugated systems to cause efficient energy transfer from ligand to the Tb3+ center. Thus, 1′ exhibits the characteristic enhanced luminescent emissions at λmax values of 490, 544, 584, 622 nm, upon excitation at 350 nm, which can be assigned to 5D4 → 7F6, 5D4 → 7F5, 5D4 → 7F4, and 5D4 → 7F3 transitions, respectively. The emission arising from the free ligand (λmax ∼ 460 nm for H3L) is not observed here. The absence of ligand-based emission in 1′ indicates efficient energy transfer from the ligand to the Tb3+ center (“antenna effect”) greatly enhancing the optical performance of the metal ion. The most prominent characteristic emission peak of 1′ at 544 nm makes it bright green under standard UV lamp visible by the naked eye, which is an added advantage for its sensory application. Due to such luminescence property of 1′, its emission characteristics with different electron-deficient NACs and metal ions were probed. The 3D MOF can act as a host for small guest molecules, and energy transfer between them can produce a strong synergistic effect for the recognition of specific guest molecules. The complex 1′ was finely powdered and then dispersed in different selected analyte solutions to investigate its luminescence properties.
elements.clean_text: The solid-state photoluminescence spectra of the free linker (H3L) and 1' were measured under ambient conditions by exciting at 345 and 350 nm respectively (). It is well-known that Tb3+ ion exhibits luminescence properties due to f-f transitions that are both spin- and parity-forbidden, thereby having low intensity. However, its emission intensity can be enhanced by integrating Tb3+ ions with conjugated systems to cause efficient energy transfer from ligand to the Tb3+ center. Thus, 1' exhibits the characteristic enhanced luminescent emissions at λmax values of 490, 544, 584, 622 nm, upon excitation at 350 nm, which can be assigned to 5D4 → 7F6, 5D4 → 7F5, 5D4 → 7F4, and 5D4 → 7F3 transitions, respectively. The emission arising from the free ligand (λmax ~ 460 nm for H3L) is not observed here. The absence of ligand-based emission in 1' indicates efficient energy transfer from the ligand to the Tb3+ center ("antenna effect") greatly enhancing the optical performance of the metal ion. The most prominent characteristic emission peak of 1' at 544 nm makes it bright green under standard UV lamp visible by the naked eye, which is an added advantage for its sensory application. Due to such luminescence property of 1', its emission characteristics with different electron-deficient NACs and metal ions were probed. The 3D MOF can act as a host for small guest molecules, and energy transfer between them can produce a strong synergistic effect for the recognition of specific guest molecules. The complex 1' was finely powdered and then dispersed in different selected analyte solutions to investigate its luminescence properties.

elements.content: Solid state luminescence spectrum of H3L and that of 1′.
elements.clean_text: 4  Solid state luminescence spectrum of H3L and that of 1'.

elements.content: Compound 1′ was first dispersed in different commonly used organic solvents like N,N′-dimethylacetamide (DMA), N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF), ethanol (EtOH), acetonitrile (MeCN), dioxane, tetrahydrofuran (THF), benzene, and toluene as well as nitrobenzene (NB). Interestingly, it was observed that only in nitrobenzene (NB) solvent the emission was completely quenched while, with the other solvents, the variation of emission intensity was not discernible ().
elements.clean_text: Compound 1' was first dispersed in different commonly used organic solvents like N,N'-dimethylacetamide (DMA), N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF), ethanol (EtOH), acetonitrile (MeCN), dioxane, tetrahydrofuran (THF), benzene, and toluene as well as nitrobenzene (NB). Interestingly, it was observed that only in nitrobenzene (NB) solvent the emission was completely quenched while, with the other solvents, the variation of emission intensity was not discernible ().

elements.content: (a) Luminescence spectra of 1′ in different solvents, (b) bar diagram representation of the 5D4 → 7F5 transition at 544 nm in different solvents, and (c) visual response of 1′ in various solvents monitored under UV light.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Luminescence spectra of 1' in different solvents, (b) bar diagram representation of the 5D4 → 7F5 transition at 544 nm in different solvents, and (c) visual response of 1' in various solvents monitored under UV light.

elements.content: This observation provided the scope to explore the sensing ability of 1′ toward other nitroaromatic compounds. Hence, DMF solutions (1 mM) of different nitroaromatic compounds, viz., nitrobenzene (NB), 1,4-dinitrobenzene (1,4-DNB), 2,4-dinitrochlorobenzene (DNCB), p-nitrophenol (NP), and 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), were prepared. Each of these solutions (1 mL) was added to a fixed amount of DMF-suspended 1′ (0.1 mL of stock solution). Significant quenching was observed in each case (a). The extent of quenching was calculated by using the equation (I 0 – I)/I 0 × 100%, where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities of the stock solution of 1′ before and after the addition of the NAC analyte, respectively. Due to high concentration of the NAC analytes with respect to stock solution, the emission intensity almost completely quenches in each case. To evaluate the quenching constant, quantitative measurements were performed (Figures S17–S21) with lower dilution of the NAC analytes and by using the Stern–Volmer (SV) equation (I 0/I) = K SV[A]+1, where I 0 represents the initial intensity of 1′ in the absence of analyte, I is the emission intensity in the presence of analyte with molar concentration [A], and K SV is the quenching constant (M–1). The quenching efficiency by the analytes is in the following order: TNP > 4NP > DNCB > 1,4-DNB > NB (b).
elements.clean_text: This observation provided the scope to explore the sensing ability of 1' toward other nitroaromatic compounds. Hence, DMF solutions (1 mM) of different nitroaromatic compounds, viz., nitrobenzene (NB), 1,4-dinitrobenzene (1,4-DNB), 2,4-dinitrochlorobenzene (DNCB), p-nitrophenol (NP), and 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), were prepared. Each of these solutions (1 mL) was added to a fixed amount of DMF-suspended 1' (0.1 mL of stock solution). Significant quenching was observed in each case (a). The extent of quenching was calculated by using the equation (I 0 - I)/I 0 × 100%, where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities of the stock solution of 1' before and after the addition of the NAC analyte, respectively. Due to high concentration of the NAC analytes with respect to stock solution, the emission intensity almost completely quenches in each case. To evaluate the quenching constant, quantitative measurements were performed (Figures S17-S21) with lower dilution of the NAC analytes and by using the Stern-Volmer (SV) equation (I 0/I) = K SV[A]+1, where I 0 represents the initial intensity of 1' in the absence of analyte, I is the emission intensity in the presence of analyte with molar concentration [A], and K SV is the quenching constant (M-1). The quenching efficiency by the analytes is in the following order: TNP > 4NP > DNCB > 1,4-DNB > NB (b).

elements.content: (a) Quenching efficiency of 1′ in the presence of different nitroarmatic compounds (1 mM) and (b) corresponding Stern–Volmer plots of NAC analytes.
elements.clean_text: 6  (a) Quenching efficiency of 1' in the presence of different nitroarmatic compounds (1 mM) and (b) corresponding Stern-Volmer plots of NAC analytes.

elements.content: To examine the potential of 1′ for sensing of the metal ions, DMF solutions containing different metal ions (0.1 M solution of nitrate salts of Li+, Na+, K+, Mg2+, Al3+, Cr3+, Mn2+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Pb2+, and perchlorate salt of Fe2+) were added separately into a fixed amount of the stock dispersion of 1′. The luminescence intensity quenched in the presence of Fe3+ ions while a moderate intensity reduction was observed upon the addition of Fe2+ or Cu2+ ions. Other metal ions do not alter the intensity to any noticeable extent as shown in .
elements.clean_text: To examine the potential of 1' for sensing of the metal ions, DMF solutions containing different metal ions (0.1 M solution of nitrate salts of Li+, Na+, K+, Mg2+, Al3+, Cr3+, Mn2+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Pb2+, and perchlorate salt of Fe2+) were added separately into a fixed amount of the stock dispersion of 1'. The luminescence intensity quenched in the presence of Fe3+ ions while a moderate intensity reduction was observed upon the addition of Fe2+ or Cu2+ ions. Other metal ions do not alter the intensity to any noticeable extent as shown in .

elements.content: (a) Luminescence intensity of 1′ in the presence of different metal ions (0.1 M) in DMF solution and (b) bar diagram representation of relative intensity of the same.
elements.clean_text: 7  (a) Luminescence intensity of 1' in the presence of different metal ions (0.1 M) in DMF solution and (b) bar diagram representation of relative intensity of the same.

elements.content: Interference by other metal ions with the detection of Fe3+ ion was investigated by competitive experiments. The results indicated that the presence of other metal ions did not make any significant change in the sensing of Fe3+ ions (Figure S23). Quantitative emission titration experiments were also performed with Fe3+ ions. With the increasing concentration of Fe­(III), the emission intensity of DMF-suspended stock solution of 1′ decreased gradually (in the concentration range of 10–6 to 10–2 M) as shown in a and S24. In the concentration range of 10–4 to 10–3 M, a good linear correlation (R 2 = 0.99243) between the quenching efficiency and the amount of Fe3+ was observed (b).
elements.clean_text: Interference by other metal ions with the detection of Fe3+ ion was investigated by competitive experiments. The results indicated that the presence of other metal ions did not make any significant change in the sensing of Fe3+ ions (Figure S23). Quantitative emission titration experiments were also performed with Fe3+ ions. With the increasing concentration of Fe(III), the emission intensity of DMF-suspended stock solution of 1' decreased gradually (in the concentration range of 10-6 to 10-2 M) as shown in a and S24. In the concentration range of 10-4 to 10-3 M, a good linear correlation (R 2 = 0.99243) between the quenching efficiency and the amount of Fe3+ was observed (b).

elements.content: (a) Variation of luminescence intensity of 1′ suspension with different concentrations of Fe­(NO3)3 and (b) corresponding Stern–Volmer plot.
elements.clean_text: 8  (a) Variation of luminescence intensity of 1' suspension with different concentrations of Fe(NO3)3 and (b) corresponding Stern-Volmer plot.

elements.content: For probing reversibility of the luminescence property of 1′, it was dispersed in a DMF solution of ferric nitrate/trinitrophenol and centrifuged after 1 day. After washing several times with fresh DMF, the luminescence intensity of 1′ was measured. Variation of the luminescence intensity was not significant at least up to three sensing–recovery cycles in either case indicating reversibility of sensing (Figure S25).
elements.clean_text: For probing reversibility of the luminescence property of 1', it was dispersed in a DMF solution of ferric nitrate/trinitrophenol and centrifuged after 1 day. After washing several times with fresh DMF, the luminescence intensity of 1' was measured. Variation of the luminescence intensity was not significant at least up to three sensing-recovery cycles in either case indicating reversibility of sensing (Figure S25).

elements.content: The probable mechanism for quenching of emission of 1′ in the presence of the experimental analytes might be due to alternation in crystal structure, metal ion exchange, host–guest interactions, or competition of absorption of excitation energy between the MOF and the analytes. The PXRD patterns of 1, NAC-immersed 1′, and 1′ immersed in a metal salt solution (ferric nitrate, cupric nitrate) showed good agreement, suggesting that the basic framework remained unaltered (Figures S22, S26). An examination of the IR spectra of 1 and nitrobenzene immersed 1 showed the peaks in 1 to be broadened and slightly red-shifted with respect to those of the pure crystals of 1 (Figure S27), suggesting interactions of nitrobenzene with the host framework. It is, therefore, presumed that the NACs, being electron-deficient in nature, can interact with the electron-rich cavity of the framework leading to quenching of the emission of 1′.
elements.clean_text:
Probable Mechanism of Sensing

The probable mechanism for quenching of emission of 1' in the presence of the experimental analytes might be due to alternation in crystal structure, metal ion exchange, host-guest interactions, or competition of absorption of excitation energy between the MOF and the analytes. The PXRD patterns of 1, NAC-immersed 1', and 1' immersed in a metal salt solution (ferric nitrate, cupric nitrate) showed good agreement, suggesting that the basic framework remained unaltered (Figures S22, S26). An examination of the IR spectra of 1 and nitrobenzene immersed 1 showed the peaks in 1 to be broadened and slightly red-shifted with respect to those of the pure crystals of 1 (Figure S27), suggesting interactions of nitrobenzene with the host framework. It is, therefore, presumed that the NACs, being electron-deficient in nature, can interact with the electron-rich cavity of the framework leading to quenching of the emission of 1'.

elements.content: For probing the Fe3+ induced quenching, the possibility of transmetalation was investigated. However, no transmetalation reaction in 1 was observed upon keeping crystals of 1 in a 0.5 M DMF solution of ferric nitrate even after 7 d at RT as proven by the EDS experiments (Table S3). It is presumed, therefore, that there might exist a competitive absorption of excitation energy between Fe­(III) ions and 1′ which diminishes the essential energy requirement for the antenna effect. The overlapping of the absorption band of a DMF solution of Fe­(III) ion (strong absorption in the range of 250–500 nm) and the excitation spectrum of 1′ (∼350 nm) also indicates this possibility (Figure S28). Similar observations were found in earlier cases as well.
elements.clean_text: For probing the Fe3+ induced quenching, the possibility of transmetalation was investigated. However, no transmetalation reaction in 1 was observed upon keeping crystals of 1 in a 0.5 M DMF solution of ferric nitrate even after 7 d at RT as proven by the EDS experiments (Table S3). It is presumed, therefore, that there might exist a competitive absorption of excitation energy between Fe(III) ions and 1' which diminishes the essential energy requirement for the antenna effect. The overlapping of the absorption band of a DMF solution of Fe(III) ion (strong absorption in the range of 250-500 nm) and the excitation spectrum of 1' (~350 nm) also indicates this possibility (Figure S28). Similar observations were found in earlier cases as well.

elements.content: A new luminescent 3D porous Tb-MOF which contains free hydroxyl group in the channels was synthesized and characterized. This framework has established another example as a potential probe for sensing nitroaromatic compounds as well as cation sensing. The dispersed solution of activated 1 in DMF medium reveals a selective and remarkable quenching effect in the presence of Fe­(III) ions and moderately toward Fe­(II)/Cu­(II) ions. Such sensing of NACs and Fe­(III) is reversible in nature and probably occurred through host–guest interaction and competitive absorption of excitation energy, respectively. Other lanthanide-MOFs with this ligand have been synthesized, and further studies are currently underway to examine their potential applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A new luminescent 3D porous Tb-MOF which contains free hydroxyl group in the channels was synthesized and characterized. This framework has established another example as a potential probe for sensing nitroaromatic compounds as well as cation sensing. The dispersed solution of activated 1 in DMF medium reveals a selective and remarkable quenching effect in the presence of Fe(III) ions and moderately toward Fe(II)/Cu(II) ions. Such sensing of NACs and Fe(III) is reversible in nature and probably occurred through host-guest interaction and competitive absorption of excitation energy, respectively. Other lanthanide-MOFs with this ligand have been synthesized, and further studies are currently underway to examine their potential applications.

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis of the linker H3L could be achieved in several steps as illustrated in . Details of the synthetic procedure are given in the Supporting Information.

Synthesis of the Complex: {[Tb­(<italic>L</italic>)­(DMA)]·(DMA)·(0.5H<sub>2</sub>O)}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

This was synthesized by mixing H3L (0.030 g, 0.1 mmol), Tb­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.09 g, 0.2 mmol), DMA (2 mL), and H2O (1 mL) in a Teflon-lined autoclave that was heated under autogenous pressure at 100 °C for 72 h followed by slow cooling to room temperature. The resulting colorless needle-shaped crystals were isolated by filtration in ∼45% yield based on H3L. Anal. Calcd for C23H26N2O9.5Tb: C, 43.07; H, 4.09; N, 4.37%. Found: C, 43.55; H, 4.27; N, 4.17%. IR (cm–1): 3428­(br), 2927(s), 1618­(m), 1518(s), 1454(s), 1375(s), 1296(s), 1211(s), 1010(s), 774(s), 731(s) (Figure S12).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Ligand

Synthesis of the linker H3L could be achieved in several steps as illustrated in . Details of the synthetic procedure are given in the Supporting Information.

Synthesis of the Complex: {[Tb(L)(DMA)]⋅(DMA)⋅(0.5H2O)} n  (1)

This was synthesized by mixing H3L (0.030 g, 0.1 mmol), Tb(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.09 g, 0.2 mmol), DMA (2 mL), and H2O (1 mL) in a Teflon-lined autoclave that was heated under autogenous pressure at 100 °C for 72 h followed by slow cooling to room temperature. The resulting colorless needle-shaped crystals were isolated by filtration in ~45% yield based on H3L. Anal. Calcd for C23H26N2O9.5Tb: C, 43.07; H, 4.09; N, 4.37%. Found: C, 43.55; H, 4.27; N, 4.17%. IR (cm-1): 3428(br), 2927(s), 1618(m), 1518(s), 1454(s), 1375(s), 1296(s), 1211(s), 1010(s), 774(s), 731(s) (Figure S12).

cln_elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis reveals that the PMOF loses 15% of its weight (calculated 14.98%) up to 120 °C, which corresponds to the loss of lattice water and DMA molecules. The coordinated DMA molecules are removed at higher temperature (up to 270 °C) showing a weight loss of 14% (calculated 13.57%). Complete decomposition of the compound is achieved beyond 400 °C (Figure S13). The powder X-ray diffraction pattern of the synthesized crystals also agrees well with the simulated pattern and confirmed its phase purity. Furthermore, the VT-PXRD data indicate that the overall framework integrity of 1 is retained at temperatures at least up to 150 °C (Figure S14). Single crystals of 1 were kept in EtOH for a week and then heated to 120 °C under 1 mm pressure for 10 h to obtain the activated compound 1′. The powder pattern of 1′ matched well with the original complex 1 (Figure S14). Due to the porous character of the framework and availability of surface functionalized channels of 1, gas adsorption studies were conducted up to a relative pressure (p/p o) of 1.0 bar. Gas adsorption characteristics of 1′ were not significant and hence not pursued further (Figure S29).
cln_elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analysis reveals that the PMOF loses 15% of its weight (calculated 14.98%) up to 120 °C, which corresponds to the loss of lattice water and DMA molecules. The coordinated DMA molecules are removed at higher temperature (up to 270 °C) showing a weight loss of 14% (calculated 13.57%). Complete decomposition of the compound is achieved beyond 400 °C (Figure S13). The powder X-ray diffraction pattern of the synthesized crystals also agrees well with the simulated pattern and confirmed its phase purity. Furthermore, the VT-PXRD data indicate that the overall framework integrity of 1 is retained at temperatures at least up to 150 °C (Figure S14). Single crystals of 1 were kept in EtOH for a week and then heated to 120 °C under 1 mm pressure for 10 h to obtain the activated compound 1'. The powder pattern of 1' matched well with the original complex 1 (Figure S14). Due to the porous character of the framework and availability of surface functionalized channels of 1, gas adsorption studies were conducted up to a relative pressure (p/p o) of 1.0 bar. Gas adsorption characteristics of 1' were not significant and hence not pursued further (Figure S29).

metadata.title:
A Luminescent Terbium MOF Containing Hydroxyl Groups
Exhibits Selective Sensing of Nitroaromatic Compounds and Fe(III)
Ions
